attraction_reviewComments: Walking down the main street and found Bubblegum Alley, between 2 stores. It is gross, but worth a peek, for a few minutes.
This alley is so cool. It is gross but entirely fascinating. It's something to see but it's just a five minute experience.
It was just by chance that we happened upon this bubblegum alley. My daughter was not real impressed. I had a good laugh. I liked to see how artistic people can be with... read more
While out walking around it is a fun spot to check out. I can at least take comfort in the fact it wasn't all one person doing the chewing.
I love seeing people reactions to the photos of this place, we heard about it and as we were in the area thought we'd hunt it down. It was really rather disgusting, but funny to... read more
It's a little gross sice there are literally thousands (mor like hindreds of thousands) of people's gum on the wall...not sanitary! But, I like it because it is interesting and I... read more
We stopped by this little curiosity while exploring downtown. The legend is more impressive than the actual site, which is really just a bunch of gum and wrappers stuck to a... read more
Started out years ago with students getting rid of chewing gum and it has grown to what it is today; a novelty place known all over the world. Go see it for yourself.
The history is fascinating. Ou could do a photo stop here after the CA 1 drive. San luis obiespo is a beautiful town and you could walk around the downtown where the alley is... read more
For some odd reason, bubblegum alley gets a lot of attention and is one the "attractions" to see. We came across it by accident and I have to say it was quite disgusting and had... read more
It's like no other alley you have seen before. It's local tradition to stick your chewed up gum on the alley wall. It's gross and stinky, but it is definitely a must see when u... read more
Dark, smelly alley with chewing gum covering the walls. Unbelievable. This ranks right up there with the Springfield Tire Fire. It's really cool to be able to say you've seen... read more
The alley is literally full of chewed gum which is gross but I'm glad that we stopped to see it, it was kind of fun to add to it too
Fun, silly thing to see when you visit SLO. They say it started as a senior class, high school thing --- some say it was par at of a rivalry between the local high school and... read more
It was kinda gross but pretty neat at the same time to see messages and see all the different places people came from to see the ally

This was a very interesting site, loaded with gum wads but kind of gross at the same time. But it is something to see so you can say you saw it or even add to it if you choose
You need a strong stomach and good sense of humor to make good by this experience...Still, like rubber necking on a freeway, it is hard to resist.

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Juan Capistrano (/sæn ˌwɑːn kæpᵻˈstrɑːnoʊ/; [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. The current OMB metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County Area is "Santa Ana-Anaheim-Irvine, CA." The population was 34,593 at the 2010 census, up from 33,826 at the 2000 census. The city was created around Mission San Juan Capistrano, and many of the homes and strip malls resemble the Spanish architecture that composes the building. It is home to the widest variety of homes in Orange County, including those built prior to 1900 in its central district (some being adobes from the 18th century). San Juan Capistrano formerly hosted a population of cliff swallows that migrate each year from Argentina to the Mission San Juan Capistrano.
